It's my church cause I live nearby! I love going into church. I meet nice people there.

is a Roman Catholic church located in the 17th arrondissement of Paris, France. It is dedicated to Saint Odile, the patron saint of Alsace.  The church was built between 1935 and 1946 in the Art Deco style. It is a rare example of Art Deco architecture among the churches of Paris. The church's bell tower, at 72 meters high, is the tallest in Paris.  The church's interior is decorated with stained glass windows, mosaics, and sculptures. The stained glass windows are particularly notable for their use of Art Deco motifs.  The church is a popular tourist attraction and is a must-see for any visitor to the 17th arrondissement.  Additional details:  The church is located at 2, avenue St√©phane-Mallarm√©. It is open from 8am to 7pm. The entrance is free. The church is wheelchair accessible. Here are some of the things you can see and do at √âglise Sainte-Odile:  Take a tour of the church and learn about its history and architecture. See the stained glass windows, mosaics, and sculptures. Attend a Mass or other religious service. Visit the church's gift shop. √âglise Sainte-Odile is a beautiful and historic church that is a must-see for any visitor to Paris. It is a great place to experience the city's rich religious heritage and to learn about the life of Saint Odile.

Completed in 1946, it is one of the most beautiful churches in Paris. Its Art Deco-inspired interior is captivatingly beautiful. Its three bays of stained glass are a masterpiece of 20th century glassmaking art.
Truly spectacular architecture, very modern, and above all, inside, a height that feels really good. The stained glass windows are very colorful, it is a beautiful church.
Church with modern architecture. Very sober interior with beautiful stained glass windows.

The church is pink with bricks taken from a quarry in Belgium, Byzantine architectural style, with 3 domes symbolizing the Holy Trinity. This is a church with a 72m high bell tower, the highest in Paris. Pleasant space, beautiful sparkling glass paintings, is a place not to be missed for those who go on pilgrimage in Paris and love unique churches.
Magnificent church both outside and inside! A captivating atmosphere reigns there. Little known but definitely worth the detour.

Church listed as a historic monument. Dating from 1934, construction lasted 11 years. The exterior architecture, the portal, the stained glass windows are sublime. Special mention to the decagonal bell tower housing a carillon of twenty-three bells which is impressive.
Precious temple, worth the trip. Brick architecture to perfection. Beautiful sculptures and stained glass windows.
Beautiful recent church. Its chime is very very large. This church is surprising: its left side is blind while the right side is extremely light thanks to these large stained glass windows.
Very beautiful architecture, beautiful stained glass windows
I felt very good in that church and there was also the image of my Jesus of Divine Mercy.

Church from the 1930s housing art deco works, notably the enamel altarpiece and the immense glass roof of the nave. Its bell tower, the tallest in Paris, is as high as the church is long (72m). Huge crypt in the basement. Masses every day in French and Latin. Dynamic social activities (solidarity locker room, food distribution, academic support, etc.). Numerous spiritual activities (training, conferences, chaplaincy, etc.).
The right side is completely stained glass, the inside is quite nice and magnificent. One of the eye-catching architectural structures of the modern period. Worth seeing ‚≠ê
Notre Dame du Mordor et de l'Isengard is an original church, strange even, but of great beauty.
Simple, a little austere, to see for its art deco style, its calm and serenity
Warm welcome the day after the feast of Saint Odile which takes place every December 13  Prayer aloud by a priest of the Sainte Odile Church outside of mass hours.
A beautiful contemporary church, very welcoming and with very good lighting.
I went when I lived in Savigny s Orge.
Monument with impressive architecture.
Very beautiful church, unusual decoration!
Superb Church. Held by a very far-sighted person.
Visit this church on the edge of Paris, classified as a historic monument
Imposing church, architecture different from what is done in the 17th! Magnificent stained glass windows!  To admire if you pass in the area!

This church is indeed a masterpiece of the 20th century.  Altarpiece unique in the world for its size, a magnificently decorated altar and 3 huge glass roofs - not stained glass windows - absolutely superb. Considering the configuration of the land granted, the architect did a remarkable job. Very nice discovery but to fully enjoy the visit, I recommend a guided tour (on the Art Culture et Foi website) and especially to wait for the reopening of the Ste-Odile square currently closed for work, which allows you to see the exterior from the right side as well as the 3 domes on the roof. Finally, the church has no setback, and the right side is blind because it adjoins a building. However, avenue St√©phane Mallarm√© is undergoing major work until spring 2023 to install the tramway. The place is also constantly congested because of this work. Better to come by bus (163 - Porte de Courcelles stop) or by metro.
Recent church near the Porte d'Asni√®res.  Beautiful collected atmosphere and simple decoration. Lovely stained glass windows on one side of the building.. worth a look...

Wonderful church, even if the outside looks weird the first time Stained glass windows to see and see again, saints from the Middle Ages Beautiful liturgy on Sunday at 9:30 a.m. in extraordinary form...provided that Mgr Aupetit confirms this "authorization"..

Magnificent stained glass windows in this beautiful church built from 1935 to 1946 by the architect Jacques Barge (1904-1979) from Ch√¢teauroux. The panels around the choir (altarpiece) in embossed copper covered with translucent enamel are the work of the artist Robert Barriot, also born in Ch√¢teauroux in 1898.

This is the church where I made my first communion, my confirmation and my Solannelle Communion. Good memories, 50 meters from the slums of the Paris belt, then Levallois. From 1959 to 1965, from the age of 6 to 13, it was like this: the very poor and the rich of the 17th arrondissement lived together.

Amazing church, whose bell tower rises very high into the sky like an enormous chimney trying to touch the sky... Of resolutely modern architecture, its construction began on March 24, 1935 and was completed on November 17, 1946... Mgr Edmond Loutil dedicates the church to Saint Odile, patron saint of Alsace where his mother comes from. The interior also seems disproportionate and there is less privacy than in traditional churches, in my opinion, which are better suited to gathering in small, intimate corners.... I prefer older churches which I only give it 4*!
